text: Any examples of back-to-lay (or lay-to-back) inplay where the lay bet is only placed based on the back bet filling? Assuming this is probably easiest if you create a limit order and cancel it if it isn't filled in a specified time period. Then get the amount matched after the time period and place the lay bet. (Adding to lay as back is progressively filled seems quite a bit more complicated)

elements.text: Any examples of back-to-lay (or lay-to-back) inplay where the lay bet is only placed based on the back bet filling? elements.text: awesome thanks for your help

text:
Something like this (reference for anyone wondering):
```def process_orders(self, market, orders):
    for order in orders:
        # kill order if unmatched in market for greater than 5 seconds
        if order.status == OrderStatus.EXECUTABLE and order.side == 'BACK':
            if order.elapsed_seconds and order.elapsed_seconds > 5:
                market.cancel_order(order)

        # create lay order if back order was matched  
        if order.status == OrderStatus.EXECUTION_COMPLETE and order.size_matched > 0:
            
            market_id, selection_id, handicap = order.lookup
            
            trade = Trade(
                market_id=market_id,
                selection_id=selection_id,
                handicap=handicap,
                strategy=self,
            )
            # create order
            order = trade.create_order(
                side="LAY",
                order_type=LimitOrder(lay_price, order.size_matched),
            )
            # place order for execution
            market.place_order(order)```

text:
This should handly it pretty easily?
```            # create lay order if back order was matched  
            if order.status == OrderStatus.EXECUTION_COMPLETE and order.size_matched > 0:
                
                market_id, selection_id, handicap = order.lookup
                
                runner_context = self.get_runner_context(
                        market_id, selection_id
                    )
                if runner_context.trade_count == 1:
                
                    trade = Trade(
                        market_id=market_id,
                        selection_id=selection_id,
                        handicap=handicap,
                        strategy=self,
                    )
                    # create order
                    order = trade.create_order(
                        side="LAY",
                        order_type=LimitOrder(lay_price, order.size_matched),
                    )
                    # place order for execution
                    market.place_order(order)```

text: What sort of POT figures to people consider respectable, and why is it important? I've just calculated the statistic for a model I'm calibrating. Just considering the back side, the POT is 0.6%.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: What sort of POT figures to people consider respectable, and why is it important? I've just calculated the statistic for a model I'm calibrating. Just considering the back side, the POT is 0.6%.

text: For pre-play I would generally want more than 1% profit on stakes. 0.6% is a little low, since you're likely to loose a little to slippage / moving the market if you are taking volume once you go live. Or if you are offering then you'll have unmodelled adverse selection. 0.6% is just a bit too low on margin for it to be realistic and scalable. Might depend on when you are trading though, and how much you are trading (combining backs and lays) vs taking large outright bets.

elements.text: For pre-play I would generally want more than 1% profit on stakes. 0.6% is a little low, since you're likely to loose a little to slippage / moving the market if you are taking volume once you go live. Or if you are offering then you'll have unmodelled adverse selection. 0.6% is just a bit too low on margin for it to be realistic and scalable. Might depend on when you are trading though, and how much you are trading (combining backs and lays) vs taking large outright bets.

text: If you are taking large outright bets, then only a 0.6% margin will give you massive drawdowns. Really want more than 2-3% edge if you are just placing one-sided bets.

elements.text: If you are taking large outright bets, then only a 0.6% margin will give you massive drawdowns. Really want more than 2-3% edge if you are just placing one-sided bets.

text: If you're taking, you can always simulate sensitivity to latency (slippage), but you won't be able to simulate how much you might move the market. Also I don't know how flumine simulates taking volume (e.g. does it simulate removing it from the book so you can't take it twice?)

elements.text: If you're taking, you can always simulate sensitivity to latency (slippage), but you won't be able to simulate how much you might move the market. Also I don't know how flumine simulates taking volume (e.g. does it simulate removing it from the book so you can't take it twice?)

text: At the moment, I don't think it simulates taking volume. By default it has 0.15 seconds of latency, but I increased it to 0.5 seconds for safety.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: At the moment, I don't think it simulates taking volume. By default it has 0.15 seconds of latency, but I increased it to 0.5 seconds for safety.

text: 0.5 secs is very conservative. I use 0.15 as standard as well. You should do another sim using 0.15 and then 0.0 to see whether it performs much better. If it does, it'll mean others are chasing the same prices as you. 0.15 is realistically achievable though, so you might find your margin is actually better.

elements.text: 0.5 secs is very conservative. I use 0.15 as standard as well. You should do another sim using 0.15 and then 0.0 to see whether it performs much better. If it does, it'll mean others are chasing the same prices as you. 0.15 is realistically achievable though, so you might find your margin is actually better.

text:
I'd test with more data, and see whether you have a decent edge betting outright or not (no hedge). But that's a riskier route. You'd want a few months of data.

If your strategy is purely price action based then you're never going to get a massive margin when taking volume anyway. Offering may be better, but that's harder to test.

I'd recommend just trying it live with small stakes and see whether you can realise that 0.6% or not. If your backtest says you should be getting 95% positive days when hedging out, but the first day you try you lose money, then you can quickly just say it's back to the drawing board.

You're probably not far off having something though.

elements.text:
I'd test with more data, and see whether you have a decent edge betting outright or not (no hedge). But that's a riskier route. You'd want a few months of data.

If your strategy is purely price action based then you're never going to get a massive margin when taking volume anyway. Offering may be better, but that's harder to test.

I'd recommend just trying it live with small stakes and see whether you can realise that 0.6% or not. If your backtest says you should be getting 95% positive days when hedging out, but the first day you try you lose money, then you can quickly just say it's back to the drawing board.

You're probably not far off having something though.
